image.altText: A man walking in a suit outside court

items.synopsis: Adam Cranston is one of five people found guilty of two charges over various roles in the Plutus Payroll scam, which ran for about three years to 2017.

title.children: Judge 'flabbergasted' legal aid pulled for one of architects of $105m tax fraud

image.altText: Jana Pittman, in green and gold lycra top and bottom, smiles widely holding the outstretched Australian flag, with crowd behind.

items.synopsis: When the media turned on her after the 2004 Athens Olympics, Jana Pittman was filled with self-doubt, and it wasn't the first time. Here's how she turned things around.

title.children: Jana Pittman is a former world champion, a mum of six and a doctor. But her 'greatest success' is something else

image.altText: A woman with bright-red dyed hair smiles for the camera

items.synopsis: A coronial inquest has been told a Mullumbimby woman who died minutes after using Kambo frog poison was not properly advised about the risks involved.

title.children: Natascha Lechner not told about risk of sudden death from frog poison vomiting ritual, inquest told

image.altText: Man in a yellow hoodie standing next to a protester holding a sign shouting.

items.synopsis: At this stage, the UK government won't say how much it's spending on the coronation, but some estimates put it at between $90-180 million — while a recent poll found 51 per cent of Brits believed the coronation shouldn't be taxpayer-funded.

title.children: King Charles III's immense wealth questioned as coronation sparks protests

image.altText: Man walks up stairs with piece of paper in hand

items.synopsis: Police says the disappearance of Zoran Popovski, who was last seen crossing a road in south Sydney almost a month ago, is suspicious and they are calling on the public to help them find the 54-year-old.

title.children: CCTV shows Sydney man's last-known movements as riot police join search three weeks after he vanished

image.altText: A 3d illustration of a cat-like creature

items.synopsis: Researchers delving into Wellington Caves in western NSW say bone fracture patterns indicate that many of them had fallen through a hole in the cave ceiling and remained buried there, waiting to be discovered.

title.children: Mystery solved into how giant marsupial lion got to be in caves

image.altText: A blue sign with white writing on a building that reads "Jenny Craig".

items.synopsis: Jenny Craig centres will continue to operate in Australia despite reports the company plans to file for bankruptcy and close in the United States after failing to find a buyer for the weight loss empire.

title.children: Jenny Craig's Australian operations safe as US business reportedly plans to file for bankruptcy

image.altText: Close up of two hands, palms facing upward, under a tap with running water in a sink.

items.synopsis: Residents forced to rely salty bore water for years will have access to safe drinking water within days — but a long-term staffing solution for the town's treatment plant is still required.

title.children: After five years of drinking water described as 'filth', change is finally on the way for Walgett

image.altText: Two men in suits standing together.

items.synopsis: New South Wales Nationals leader Paul Toole says there will be repercussions if party member Ben Franklin accepts an upper house president role, offered to him by close friend Premier Chris Minns.

title.children: Nationals leader won't rule out expulsion over Ben Franklin president offer

image.altText: Anika Wells speaks in parliament.

items.synopsis: The nurses union warns the aged care sector has form when it comes to avoiding paying wage rises, and says the government must oblige providers to pass on a historic 15 per cent pay increase to all workers, not just those on award rates.

title.children: Nurses union fears nursing homes won't pass on 'historic' $11.3 billion budget commitment to boost aged care wages

image.altText: A man with long hair and a beard next to another man with short, grey hair and a business suit.

items.synopsis: Mike Cannon-Brookes and Andrew "Twiggy" Forrest used to be lead investment partners on the $30 billion Sun Cable project. Now, they're bidding against each other to control it in a closed-door process close to resolution.

title.children: 'Get your act together': A town's message to two of Australia's richest men as they struggle for control over solar farm

image.altText: Vladimir Putin, wearing a dark suit, looks ahead as he sits in front of green, white, blue and red banners.

items.synopsis: Moscow is accusing Ukraine of attacking the Kremlin with drones in what it is calling a failed bid to kill Russian President Vladimir Putin.

title.children: Russia flags 'retaliatory measures' after claiming Ukraine tried to assassinate Putin with drones

image.altText: A scooter rider can be seen travelling down a bike path, followed by a police officer on a motorbike wearing body-cam.

items.synopsis: Video shows officers on motorbikes pursuing James Cole at high speed on a busy road and bike paths as the 38-year-old tries to evade them.

title.children: 'Please, it's Christmas and that': E-scooter rider pleads with police after bike path chase

image.altText: Carrie Fisher on stage in LA

items.synopsis: The Walk of Fame recognition is a May the Fourth tribute to one of the Star Wars franchise's most beloved figures.

title.children: This May the Fourth, Carrie Fisher gets Walk of Fame star

image.altText: The gates of Perilya's south mine in Broken Hill open.

items.synopsis: A number of employees and contractors working at the company Perilya may be out of a job due to a staff restructure in one of its mines.

title.children: Job losses expected at one of Broken Hill's largest mining operations

image.altText: A power station next to the ocean, as seen from above.

items.synopsis: The new gas-fired power plant will open in the region later this year and is set to transition to a 5 per cent hydrogen blend by 2025 — with the potential to ramp up to 60 per cent.

title.children: Switch from natural gas in the pipeline as Illawarra hydrogen plant opening looms

image.altText: Two men smile in an image composite.

items.synopsis: One of two police officers attacked and stabbed in SA's Mid North has been discharged from hospital while the other is showing "positive progress" following surgery for critical injuries last night, the state's police commissioner says.

title.children: Stabbed SA policeman discharged from hospital, other showing 'positive progress' following surgery

image.altText: Missy Elliot clapping and smiling with curly purple hair and a cap on

items.synopsis: The Rock & Roll Hall of Fame has announced its 2023 inductees with Missy Elliott becoming the first female hip-hop artist to be inducted.

title.children: Missy Elliott becomes first female hip-hop artist to be inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame

image.altText: colourful vapes in a pile

items.synopsis: The sale of nicotine vapes and e-cigarettes without a prescription has been illegal in Western Australia for several years, but not a single retailer has been fined in the past 12 months.

title.children: 'I'm at a loss': Parent pleads for action as authorities admit no fines have been issued for illegal sales

image.altText: A yellow M on a red square sign

items.synopsis: A South Australian McDonald's franchisee has been fined $275,000 for threatening to demote employees and reduce their hours if they joined the union.

title.children: Former McDonald's franchisee fined for 'appalling' breach of workers' rights

image.altText: Melinda McLennan with her family

items.synopsis: Currently, only one Australian state has public Mother-Baby Units in its regional areas. This mum says Australia needs to do more to support perinatal mental health.

title.children: Melinda wanted to be admitted to a Mother and Baby Unit. It was impossible in her area

image.altText: An image of the logo of the World Health Organization in Geneva.

items.synopsis: The World Health Organization says it has dismissed a senior scientist, known for his role as the head of an international mission to China to probe the origins of COVID-19, for sexual misconduct.

title.children: WHO dismisses COVID origins investigator for alleged sexual misconduct

image.altText: A mountain covered in white snow, trees and shrubs.

items.synopsis: Two men have been found in the Kosciuszko National Park overnight after activating their emergency beacon amid "foul" weather conditions.

title.children: Hikers caught in 'blizzard conditions' found in Snowy Mountains

image.altText: Tourists watch a bison as it sniffs at the fence diving it and them.

items.synopsis: A herd of bison caught up in a settlement dispute has a new home. But a dozen of the animals died before the move and the owner and another stud breeder want to know how it happened.

title.children: Surviving bison from NSW property moved, but cause of 12 deaths in herd remains a mystery

image.altText: Two police cars outside a house on a main road which is draped with police tape

items.synopsis: Students at Charles Darwin University will today hold a vigil for a 23-year-old in a critical condition following a violent home invasion.

title.children: Darwin student remains in ICU after alleged 'random' attack 'in his own bed'

image.altText: protest signs and man

items.synopsis: A prominent planner says 2032 Olympic Games visitors will struggle to get to and from the Gold Coast's airport without a controversial light rail link that residents are fighting to have stopped.

title.children: Surfing champion Mick Fanning opposes light rail project, as fears grow for Gold Coast transport ahead of Olympics

items.synopsis: Mexico's army welcomes a new search and rescue puppy, gifted from the Turkish government as a gesture of gratitude for the lifesaving work of Mexico's emergency teams following devastating earthquakes in February.

title.children: Türkiye sends pup to Mexico in gratitude for rescue dog who died saving earthquake survivors

image.altText: An image of the logo of Eli Lilly outside their corporate headquarters.

items.synopsis: An experimental Alzheimer's drug appeared to slow worsening of the mind-robbing disease in a large new study, with experts optimistic but warning of risks.

title.children: New experimental Alzheimer's drug appears to slow cognitive decline by 35 per cent

image.altText: Donald Trump wears a blue suit and red tie as he speaks into a microphone at a convention.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump denies raping writer E. Jean Carroll in a deposition video that has been played for a jury in a civil trial where the former US president is seeking to defend himself without testifying in person.

title.children: Donald Trump calls rape allegation 'ridiculous' in video played for jury

image.altText: A NAB sign with a few jacaranda branches in front of it.

items.synopsis: The ASX opens lower after NAB reports cash profit jump of 17 per cent but its shares slump more than 7 per cent as the result was below market expectations.The US Federal Reserve raises interest rates by another 0.25 of a percentage point. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: NAB shares dive on profit miss, ASX down as US Federal Reserve raises interest rates

schema.headline: Live: NAB shares dive on profit miss, ASX down as US Federal Reserve raises interest rates

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Federal budget bottomline boost could help provide households 'relief'
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Westpac chief economist Bill Evans expects the federal budget bottomline will be $110 billion better off leaving the government extra spending room in the budget. While it will need to offset an increase in aged care workers wages, he says there's a lot of money available for Treasurer Jim Chalmers to disperse thanks to the iron ore price coming in above Treasury expectations. Dr Evans expects there will be funding for households including rental relief, energy relief and that JobSeeker will be raised for people aged over 55. He says housing affordability will also be targeted. He expects multinationals will come under the microscope and there will be rising taxes for gas companies. Dr Evans says despite the extra room to spend he expects the government will exercise "a fair degree of discipline" when it comes to spending this budget. Watch Bill Evans on YouTube here.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Westpac, Macquarie join ANZ, NAB in passing on rate hike
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Westpac says following the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision on Tuesday to increase the cash rate by 0.25 per cent, the bank will pass on the rate hike to its customers. The change will be effective May 12 for existing customers and the bank said home loan variable interest rates will increase by 0.25 per cent for new and existing customers on May 16. Deposit rates for Westpac Life total variable rate with bonus interest will increase by 0.25 per cent to 4.50 per cent on May 12, while Westpac eSaver total variable rate will increase by the same amount for new customers for the first five months, on May 12. Westpac chief executive of its consumer and business banking, Chris de Bruin, said customers were looking carefully at their budgets as interest rates rise. "While many are adjusting to making higher repayments, we understand others may need extra help," he said. "To assist we're reaching out to some customers we believe may need additional support." Macquarie said it was increasing variable home loan reference rates by 0.25 percentage points, effective May 19. Macquarie’s savings account welcome rate is increasing by 0.25 percentage points for the first four months on balances up to $250,000, effective May 9.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Bank losses to remain 'low': S&P Global
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: National Australia Bank's earnings will remain sound over the next two years, despite increasing margin pressure, according to credit ratings agency S & P Global. While the bank's net interest margin across the half increased 13 basis points to 1.80 per cent, its margin for the most recent quarter was down 4 basis points. "This reflects increasing funding costs and strong competition in the Australian mortgage market despite rising interest rates," the agency said in a statement, adding that the bank's "results were solid across all business units and in line with our expectations". "NAB's credit losses should remain low at about 15 basis points in the next two years, in line with those for other major Australian banks," the statement said. "The relatively benign economic outlook, low unemployment, and strong household balance sheets should temper the risks to the Australian banking system from high inflation, rising interest rates, and low business and consumer confidence." It said NAB's capital levels should remain strong. NAB shares were trading 5.5 per cent lower at 1.15pm AEST at $26.98 off the back of its lower-than-expected profit results.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ANZ passes on RBA rate hike to borrowers
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ANZ has followed National Australia Bank in hiking mortgage rates by 25 basis points following the Reserve Bank's decision on Tuesday. It will be effective as of May 12. ANZ will also increase the rate available to savings customers on the ANZ Plus Save account for balances less than $250,000 by 0.25 per cent annually to 4.50 per cent annually, effective May 11. ANZ said it "continues to review other deposit rates". Group executive Australia retail, Maile Carnegie, said they would help customers manage their home loans where needed. "If you are facing difficulty, contact our experienced teams as early as you can to discuss additional personalised support," she said.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Jenny Craig to file for bankruptcy in US, but Australian business to operate
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Weight loss empire Jenny Craig is closing operations in the United States after 40 years, according to US media reports. The company's operations in Australia are independent of the US and will continue, a Jenny Craig spokeswoman told ABC News. "Here in Australia and New Zealand we currently continue to operate and support our clients," she said. "As always, our priority is to continue providing the best possible service." In an email sent to US employees on Tuesday (Wednesday AEDT), the company said it will close "due to its inability to secure additional financing," according to a news report from NBC. The company has about 1000 casual and corporate workers in the US. For the past two weeks, Jenny Craig had been running out of money as it searched for a buyer. Bloomberg Law reported last month that the company was pursuing a sale.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: More borrowers refinance home loans
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Refinance volumes, fuelled by rising interest rates and cost of living pressure, eclipsed new loans for the first time since early 2020 in many capital cities. The quarterly PEXA Mortgage Insights Report analyses the nation's property refinance activity and new loans trends. It found refinance volumes eclipsed new loans in New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia. The report found 98,527 refinances were completed in the aforementioned states – nearly 2,000 more than the 96,767 new loans issued during the same period. New loans had not previously dipped beneath 100,000 in a quarter since June 2020 at the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, it said. All states posted year-on-year growth in refinances, as borrowers continue to scramble for more favourable deals on their home loan amid rising interest rates. New loans to fund the purchase of property were down 17.9 per cent on the December 2022 quarter and 25.3 per cent below the figure posted in the prior year. PEXA's head of research Michael Gill said, "elevated refinancing activity is likely to continue due to the unusually high number of fixed-term loans that will be expiring in the next two years." "It will also likely be supported by the RBA strongly flagging the possibility of more rises later this year, in order to bring inflation closer to the target band of 2 to 3 per cent." A slim majority of economists in a snap Reuters poll say the Reserve Bank will likely deliver one more 25-basis-point interest rate rise by the end of September to 4.10 per cent, following its surprise rate hike on Tuesday. The RBA shocked economists and financial markets when it took the cash rate to 3.85 per cent, with RBA Governor Philip Lowe saying the central bank was "dead serious" about getting inflation under control.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Jobseeker needs to rise: Deloitte Access Economics
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is under growing pressure to provide relief to struggling areas of society when he delivers the Federal Budget next Tuesday. There's calls for the government to lift the Jobseeker payment to a 'liveable level' to help vulnerable Australians deal with the soaring cost of living, not just in food but also in services. The Treasury forecaster Deloitte Access Economics is the latest number cruncher to say Mr Chalmers needs to "do it". Listen to the ABC's Peter Ryan for more on the Deloitte report here .

liveBlogUpdate.headline: ASX opens lower
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The ASX 200 opened 0.8 per cent lower, or down 55.6 points to 7141.8, with investor sentiment dented after US stocks fell amid the Fed's latest move to raise interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point. NAB shares were trading 7.57 per cent lower at $26.39 off the back of its profit results. On Wall Street the S & P 500 closed 0.7 per cent lower. The Nasdaq Composite index was down 0.5 per cent and the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.8 per cent. Oil prices also dived, with investors worried about a weakening global economy that could dent energy demand. Brent crude was down 4.4 per cent to $US72.04 per barrel. Gold lifted 0.8 per cent to $US2039.30 an ounce. The Fed has signalled it may pause further increases, giving officials time to assess fallout from recent bank failures. US regulators on Monday seized First Republic, the third major US institution to fail in two months, with JPMorgan Chase agreeing to take US$173 billion of the bank's loans, US$30 billion of securities and US$92 billion of deposits. The European Central Bank is also set to raise interest rates for the seventh meeting in a row on Thursday to curb inflation. It comes after the Reserve Bank's shock interest rate rise this week taking the cash rate to 3.85 per cent.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Rising interest rates help drive NAB profit to $4 billion
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: National Australia Bank's statutory net profit was just shy of $4 billion for the six months to March 31, up 19 per cent on the same period a year earlier. The bank's preferred measure of cash profit lifted to $4.07 billion, propelled by business lending and margin growth. The cash profit climbed 17 per cent in the six months ended March 31, compared to the $3.48 billion in the same period last year. The result was below market expectations. NAB declared an 83c interim dividend, up from 73 cents in the same period last year. After the Reserve Bank surprised some economists with another 0.25 percentage point rise in the cash rate this week, NAB chief executive Ross McEwan said there were encouraging signs inflation and interest rates in Australia were peaking. He said the nation would avoid a "pronounced economic correction", but the full impact of the rising cost of living on households remained uncertain. He said economic growth was likely to slow, and unemployment would "drift up to around 4.7 per cent by the end of 2024". NAB is the largest lender to small businesses in the country. The bank said its total loans grew 6.2 per cent in the half and deposits were up 8.4 per cent, helped in part by its purchase of Citi's Australian retail bank last year. Margins have risen across the sector amid higher rates. The bank's net interest margin — which compares funding costs with what it charges for loans — rose 14 basis points to 1.77 per cent. Charges for impaired loans rose to $393 million, up on $2 million in the first half last year. The bank did not report a rise in mortgage arrears. The proportion of customers who were 90 days or more behind on their repayments stayed flat at 0.66 per cent. NAB CEO Ross McEwan spoke to the ABC's Peter Ryan on radio. He will be interviewed by The Business presenter Alicia Barry on tonight's program, which airs at 8:45pm AEST on ABC News Channel.

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Market snapshot at 9:20am AEST
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: ASX SPI 200 futures: -0.5% to 7,165 points Australian dollar: -0.4% to 66.42 US cents Dow Jones: -0.8% to 33,414 points S & P 500: -0.7% to 4,091 points Nasdaq: -0.5% to 12,025 points FTSE: +0.2% to 7,788 points EuroStoxx: +0.3% to 463 points Spot gold: +0.7% to $US2,053/ounce Brent crude: $US72.33 /barrel Iron ore: -1.6% to $US100.50/tonne Bitcoin: +2% at $US29,093

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Fed raises rates, sinks Wall Street
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: The big news globally overnight was the Fed's latest move to raise interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point to between 5-5.25%. The move was widely expected, and the rate hike was softened with the Fed now adopting a meeting-by-meeting approach to rates decisions, rather than leaning towards rate hikes. US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's press conference saw bond yields decline, despite the rate rise, but that wasn't enough to boost markets, with the S & P 500 index down 0.7%, the Dow Jones off 0.8% and the Nasdaq falling 0.5%. Here's the summary of what Mr Powell had to say from NAB's Taylor Nugent. "Powell said that dropping the expectation of further tightening in the statement was 'a meaningful change' but that decisions would be made meeting by meeting and "a decision on a pause was not made today. " "Powell said 'policy is tight' and relative to a sufficiently restrictive level he said "we feel like we're getting closer and maybe even there" but that it is an ongoing assessment. Ahead of the next meeting we'll get two more employment and CPI reports. " Powell pushed back on market pricing for cuts, but only by noting that the FOMC views inflation as coming down 'not so quickly'. On those inflation forecasts rate cuts would not be so forthcoming according to Powell, but the push back was conditional on that expectation for stubborn inflation. " Powell expects the US to avoid a recession, in contrast to the March Staff forecasts ." However, ANZ economists Tom Kenny and Brian Martin think the US economy is still robust enough to warrant another rate rise. "We see no grounds yet for an early pivot on interest rates," they wrote. "The change in language reflects a more adaptive approach to setting policy and the fact that effective fed funds are now in line with the median dot plot for Q4. " Our forecasts pencil in one more 25bp [basis point] rate hike (June), which reflects still strong momentum in the jobs market and elevated inflation. We do not think there is sufficient evidence yet to take further tightening off the table."

liveBlogUpdate.headline: Good morning
liveBlogUpdate.articleBody: Nassim Khadem and myself will be taking you through today's market action along with news from across the ABC Business Reporting Team. Plenty of news around with a Fed rates decision and NAB's profit result. Join us to stay across all of it throughout the day.

liveBlogStreamPrepared.name: Live: NAB shares dive on profit miss, ASX down as US Federal Reserve raises interest rates

children.content: ANZ has followed National Australia Bank in hiking mortgage rates by 25 basis points following the Reserve Bank's decision on Tuesday.
It will be effective as of May 12.
ANZ will pass on the rate rise immediately
(ABC News)
ANZ will also increase the rate available to savings customers on the ANZ Plus Save account for balances less than $250,000 by 0.25 per cent annually to 4.50 per cent annually, effective May 11.
ANZ said it "continues to review other deposit rates".
Group executive Australia retail, Maile Carnegie, said they would help customers manage their home loans where needed.
"If you are facing difficulty, contact our experienced teams as early as you can to discuss additional personalised support," she said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Weight loss empire Jenny Craig is closing operations in the United States after 40 years, according to US media reports. The company's operations in Australia are independent of the US and will continue, a Jenny Craig spokeswoman told ABC News. "Here in Australia and New Zealand we currently continue to operate and support our clients," she said. "As always, our priority is to continue providing the best possible service." In an email sent to US employees on Tuesday (Wednesday AEDT), the company said it will close "due to its inability to secure additional financing," according to a news report from NBC. The company has about 1000 casual and corporate workers in the US. For the past two weeks, Jenny Craig had been running out of money as it searched for a buyer. Bloomberg Law reported last month that the company was pursuing a sale.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jenny Craig to file for bankruptcy in US, but Australian business to operate

children.content: Weight loss empire Jenny Craig is closing operations in the United States after 40 years, according to US media reports.
The company's operations in Australia are independent of the US and will continue, a Jenny Craig spokeswoman told ABC News.
"Here in Australia and New Zealand we currently continue to operate and support our clients," she said.

props.alt: Kirstie Alley on the red carpet

children.content: Actress Kirstie Alley used Jenny Craig's weight loss program previously
(ABC News)
"As always, our priority is to continue providing the best possible service."
In an email sent to US employees on Tuesday (Wednesday AEDT), the company said it will close "due to its inability to secure additional financing," according to a news report from NBC.
The company has about 1000 casual and corporate workers in the US.
For the past two weeks, Jenny Craig had been running out of money as it searched for a buyer.
Bloomberg Law reported last month that the company was pursuing a sale.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Refinance volumes, fuelled by rising interest rates and cost of living pressure, eclipsed new loans for the first time since early 2020 in many capital cities. The quarterly PEXA Mortgage Insights Report analyses the nation's property refinance activity and new loans trends. It found refinance volumes eclipsed new loans in New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia. The report found 98,527 refinances were completed in the aforementioned states – nearly 2,000 more than the 96,767 new loans issued during the same period. New loans had not previously dipped beneath 100,000 in a quarter since June 2020 at the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, it said. All states posted year-on-year growth in refinances, as borrowers continue to scramble for more favourable deals on their home loan amid rising interest rates. New loans to fund the purchase of property were down 17.9 per cent on the December 2022 quarter and 25.3 per cent below the figure posted in the prior year. PEXA's head of research Michael Gill said, "elevated refinancing activity is likely to continue due to the unusually high number of fixed-term loans that will be expiring in the next two years." "It will also likely be supported by the RBA strongly flagging the possibility of more rises later this year, in order to bring inflation closer to the target band of 2 to 3 per cent." A slim majority of economists in a snap Reuters poll say the Reserve Bank will likely deliver one more 25-basis-point interest rate rise by the end of September to 4.10 per cent, following its surprise rate hike on Tuesday. The RBA shocked economists and financial markets when it took the cash rate to 3.85 per cent, with RBA Governor Philip Lowe saying the central bank was "dead serious" about getting inflation under control.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More borrowers refinance home loans

children.content: Refinance volumes, fuelled by rising interest rates and cost of living pressure, eclipsed new loans for the first time since early 2020 in many capital cities.
The quarterly PEXA Mortgage Insights Report analyses the nation's property refinance activity and new loans trends.
It found refinance volumes eclipsed new loans in New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia.
The report found 98,527 refinances were completed in the aforementioned states – nearly 2,000 more than the 96,767 new loans issued during the same period.
Higgher interest rates are seeing record levels of refinancing
(ABC News)
New loans had not previously dipped beneath 100,000 in a quarter since June 2020 at the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, it said.
All states posted year-on-year growth in refinances, as borrowers continue to scramble for more favourable deals on their home loan amid rising interest rates.
New loans to fund the purchase of property were down 17.9 per cent on the December 2022 quarter and 25.3 per cent below the figure posted in the prior year.
PEXA's head of research Michael Gill said, "elevated refinancing activity is likely to continue due to the unusually high number of fixed-term loans that will be expiring in the next two years."
"It will also likely be supported by the RBA strongly flagging the possibility of more rises later this year, in order to bring inflation closer to the target band of 2 to 3 per cent."

A slim majority of economists in a snap Reuters poll say the Reserve Bank will likely deliver one more 25-basis-point interest rate rise by the end of September to 4.10 per cent, following its surprise rate hike on Tuesday.
The
RBA shocked economists and financial markets
when it took the cash rate to 3.85 per cent, with RBA Governor Philip Lowe saying the central bank was "dead serious" about getting inflation under control.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is under growing pressure to provide relief to struggling areas of society when he delivers the Federal Budget next Tuesday. There's calls for the government to lift the Jobseeker payment to a 'liveable level' to help vulnerable Australians deal with the soaring cost of living, not just in food but also in services. The Treasury forecaster Deloitte Access Economics is the latest number cruncher to say Mr Chalmers needs to "do it". Listen to the ABC's Peter Ryan for more on the Deloitte report here .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jobseeker needs to rise: Deloitte Access Economics

children.content: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is under growing pressure to provide relief to struggling areas of society when he delivers the Federal Budget next Tuesday.

props.alt: Jim Chalmers at a press conference in Canberra

children.content: Treasurer Jim Chalmers
(ABC News)
There's calls for the government to lift the Jobseeker payment to a 'liveable level' to help vulnerable Australians deal with
the soaring cost of living, not just in food but also in services.
The Treasury forecaster Deloitte Access Economics is the latest number cruncher to say Mr Chalmers needs to "do it".
Listen to the
ABC's Peter Ryan for more on the Deloitte report here

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 opened 0.8 per cent lower, or down 55.6 points to 7141.8, with investor sentiment dented after US stocks fell amid the Fed's latest move to raise interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point. NAB shares were trading 7.57 per cent lower at $26.39 off the back of its profit results. On Wall Street the S & P 500 closed 0.7 per cent lower. The Nasdaq Composite index was down 0.5 per cent and the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.8 per cent. Oil prices also dived, with investors worried about a weakening global economy that could dent energy demand. Brent crude was down 4.4 per cent to $US72.04 per barrel. Gold lifted 0.8 per cent to $US2039.30 an ounce. The Fed has signalled it may pause further increases, giving officials time to assess fallout from recent bank failures. US regulators on Monday seized First Republic, the third major US institution to fail in two months, with JPMorgan Chase agreeing to take US$173 billion of the bank's loans, US$30 billion of securities and US$92 billion of deposits. The European Central Bank is also set to raise interest rates for the seventh meeting in a row on Thursday to curb inflation. It comes after the Reserve Bank's shock interest rate rise this week taking the cash rate to 3.85 per cent.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens lower

children.content: The ASX 200 opened 0.8 per cent lower, or down 55.6 points to 7141.8, with investor sentiment dented after US stocks fell amid the Fed's latest move to raise interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point.
NAB shares were trading 7.57 per cent lower at $26.39 off the back of its profit results.
On Wall Street the S
P 500 closed 0.7 per cent lower.
The Nasdaq Composite index was down 0.5 per cent and the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.8 per cent.
Oil prices also dived, with investors worried about a weakening global economy that could dent energy demand.
Brent crude was down 4.4 per cent to $US72.04 per barrel.
Gold lifted 0.8 per cent to $US2039.30 an ounce.
The Fed has signalled it may pause further increases, giving officials time to assess fallout from recent bank failures.

US regulators on Monday seized First Republic, the third major US institution to fail in two months, with JPMorgan Chase agreeing to take US$173 billion of the bank's loans, US$30 billion of securities and US$92 billion of deposits.
The European Central Bank is also set to raise interest rates for the seventh meeting in a row on Thursday to curb inflation.
It comes after the Reserve Bank's shock interest rate rise this week taking the cash rate to 3.85 per cent.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: National Australia Bank's statutory net profit was just shy of $4 billion for the six months to March 31, up 19 per cent on the same period a year earlier. The bank's preferred measure of cash profit lifted to $4.07 billion, propelled by business lending and margin growth. The cash profit climbed 17 per cent in the six months ended March 31, compared to the $3.48 billion in the same period last year. The result was below market expectations. NAB declared an 83c interim dividend, up from 73 cents in the same period last year. After the Reserve Bank surprised some economists with another 0.25 percentage point rise in the cash rate this week, NAB chief executive Ross McEwan said there were encouraging signs inflation and interest rates in Australia were peaking. He said the nation would avoid a "pronounced economic correction", but the full impact of the rising cost of living on households remained uncertain. He said economic growth was likely to slow, and unemployment would "drift up to around 4.7 per cent by the end of 2024". NAB is the largest lender to small businesses in the country. The bank said its total loans grew 6.2 per cent in the half and deposits were up 8.4 per cent, helped in part by its purchase of Citi's Australian retail bank last year. Margins have risen across the sector amid higher rates. The bank's net interest margin — which compares funding costs with what it charges for loans — rose 14 basis points to 1.77 per cent. Charges for impaired loans rose to $393 million, up on $2 million in the first half last year. The bank did not report a rise in mortgage arrears. The proportion of customers who were 90 days or more behind on their repayments stayed flat at 0.66 per cent. NAB CEO Ross McEwan spoke to the ABC's Peter Ryan on radio. He will be interviewed by The Business presenter Alicia Barry on tonight's program, which airs at 8:45pm AEST on ABC News Channel.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rising interest rates help drive NAB profit to $4 billion

children.content: National Australia Bank's statutory net profit was just shy of $4 billion for the six months to March 31, up 19 per cent on the same period a year earlier.
The bank's preferred measure of cash profit lifted to $4.07 billion, propelled by business lending and margin growth.
Ross McEwan
(ABC News)
The cash profit climbed 17 per cent in the six months ended March 31, compared to the $3.48 billion in the same period last year. The result was below market expectations.
NAB declared an 83c interim dividend, up from 73 cents in the same period last year.

After the Reserve Bank surprised some economists with another 0.25 percentage point rise in the cash rate this week, NAB chief executive Ross McEwan said there were encouraging signs inflation and interest rates in Australia were peaking.
He said the nation would avoid a "pronounced economic correction", but the full impact of the rising cost of living on households remained uncertain.
He said economic growth was likely to slow, and unemployment would "drift up to around 4.7 per cent by the end of 2024".
NAB is the largest lender to small businesses in the country.
The bank said its total loans grew 6.2 per cent in the half and deposits were up 8.4 per cent, helped in part by its purchase of Citi's Australian retail bank last year.
Margins have risen across the sector amid higher rates. The bank's net interest margin — which compares funding costs with what it charges for loans — rose 14 basis points to 1.77 per cent.
Charges for impaired loans rose to $393 million, up on $2 million in the first half last year.
The bank did not report a rise in mortgage arrears.
The proportion of customers who were 90 days or more behind on their repayments stayed flat at 0.66 per cent.
NAB CEO Ross McEwan spoke to the
ABC's Peter Ryan on radio
. He will be interviewed by The Business presenter Alicia Barry on tonight's program, which airs at 8:45pm AEST on ABC News Channel.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The big news globally overnight was the Fed's latest move to raise interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point to between 5-5.25%. The move was widely expected, and the rate hike was softened with the Fed now adopting a meeting-by-meeting approach to rates decisions, rather than leaning towards rate hikes. US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's press conference saw bond yields decline, despite the rate rise, but that wasn't enough to boost markets, with the S & P 500 index down 0.7%, the Dow Jones off 0.8% and the Nasdaq falling 0.5%. Here's the summary of what Mr Powell had to say from NAB's Taylor Nugent. "Powell said that dropping the expectation of further tightening in the statement was 'a meaningful change' but that decisions would be made meeting by meeting and "a decision on a pause was not made today. " "Powell said 'policy is tight' and relative to a sufficiently restrictive level he said "we feel like we're getting closer and maybe even there" but that it is an ongoing assessment. Ahead of the next meeting we'll get two more employment and CPI reports. " Powell pushed back on market pricing for cuts, but only by noting that the FOMC views inflation as coming down 'not so quickly'. On those inflation forecasts rate cuts would not be so forthcoming according to Powell, but the push back was conditional on that expectation for stubborn inflation. " Powell expects the US to avoid a recession, in contrast to the March Staff forecasts ." However, ANZ economists Tom Kenny and Brian Martin think the US economy is still robust enough to warrant another rate rise. "We see no grounds yet for an early pivot on interest rates," they wrote. "The change in language reflects a more adaptive approach to setting policy and the fact that effective fed funds are now in line with the median dot plot for Q4. " Our forecasts pencil in one more 25bp [basis point] rate hike (June), which reflects still strong momentum in the jobs market and elevated inflation. We do not think there is sufficient evidence yet to take further tightening off the table."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fed raises rates, sinks Wall Street

children.content: The big news globally overnight was the Fed's latest move to
raise interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point to between 5-5.25%
The move was widely expected, and the rate hike was softened with the Fed now adopting a meeting-by-meeting approach to rates decisions, rather than leaning towards rate hikes.
US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's press conference
saw bond yields decline, despite the rate rise, but that wasn't enough to boost markets, with
the S
P 500 index down 0.7%, the Dow Jones off 0.8% and the Nasdaq falling 0.5%
Here's the summary of what Mr Powell had to say from
NAB's Taylor Nugent
"Powell said that dropping the expectation of further tightening in the statement was 'a meaningful change' but that
decisions would be made meeting by meeting and "a decision on a pause was not made today

"Powell said 'policy is tight' and relative to a sufficiently restrictive level he said "we feel like we're getting closer and maybe even there" but that it is an ongoing assessment. Ahead of the next meeting we'll get two more employment and CPI reports.
Powell pushed back on market pricing for cuts, but only by noting that the FOMC views inflation as coming down 'not so quickly'.
On those inflation forecasts rate cuts would not be so forthcoming according to Powell, but the push back was conditional on that expectation for stubborn inflation.
Powell expects the US to avoid a recession, in contrast to the March Staff forecasts
However,
ANZ economists Tom Kenny and Brian Martin
think the US economy is still robust enough to warrant another rate rise.
"We see no grounds yet for an early pivot on interest rates," they wrote.
"The change in language reflects a more adaptive approach to setting policy and the fact that effective fed funds are now in line with the median dot plot for Q4.
Our forecasts pencil in one more 25bp [basis point] rate hike (June)
, which reflects still strong momentum in the jobs market and elevated inflation. We do not think there is sufficient evidence yet to take further tightening off the table."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Nassim Khadem and myself will be taking you through today's market action along with news from across the ABC Business Reporting Team. Plenty of news around with a Fed rates decision and NAB's profit result. Join us to stay across all of it throughout the day.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Good morning

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Westpac chief economist Bill Evans expects the federal budget bottomline will be $110 billion better off leaving the government extra spending room in the budget. While it will need to offset an increase in aged care workers wages, he says there's a lot of money available for Treasurer Jim Chalmers to disperse thanks to the iron ore price coming in above Treasury expectations. Dr Evans expects there will be funding for households including rental relief, energy relief and that JobSeeker will be raised for people aged over 55. He says housing affordability will also be targeted. He expects multinationals will come under the microscope and there will be rising taxes for gas companies. Dr Evans says despite the extra room to spend he expects the government will exercise "a fair degree of discipline" when it comes to spending this budget. Watch Bill Evans on YouTube here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal budget bottomline boost could help provide households 'relief'

children.content: Westpac chief economist Bill Evans expects the federal budget bottomline will be $110 billion better off leaving the government extra spending room in the budget.
Bill Evans says higher iron ore prices will see more money for the government
(ABC News)
While it will need to offset an
increase in aged care workers wages
, he says there's a lot of money available for Treasurer Jim Chalmers to disperse thanks to the iron ore price coming in above Treasury expectations.
Dr Evans expects there will be funding for households including rental relief, energy relief and that JobSeeker will be raised for people aged over 55.
He says
housing affordability will also be targeted.
He expects multinationals will come under the microscope and there will be rising taxes for gas companies.
Dr Evans says despite the extra room to spend he expects the government will exercise "a fair degree of discipline" when it comes to spending this budget.
Watch
Bill Evans on YouTube here.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Westpac says following the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision on Tuesday to increase the cash rate by 0.25 per cent, the bank will pass on the rate hike to its customers. The change will be effective May 12 for existing customers and the bank said home loan variable interest rates will increase by 0.25 per cent for new and existing customers on May 16. Deposit rates for Westpac Life total variable rate with bonus interest will increase by 0.25 per cent to 4.50 per cent on May 12, while Westpac eSaver total variable rate will increase by the same amount for new customers for the first five months, on May 12. Westpac chief executive of its consumer and business banking, Chris de Bruin, said customers were looking carefully at their budgets as interest rates rise. "While many are adjusting to making higher repayments, we understand others may need extra help," he said. "To assist we're reaching out to some customers we believe may need additional support." Macquarie said it was increasing variable home loan reference rates by 0.25 percentage points, effective May 19. Macquarie’s savings account welcome rate is increasing by 0.25 percentage points for the first four months on balances up to $250,000, effective May 9.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Westpac, Macquarie join ANZ, NAB in passing on rate hike

children.content: Westpac says following the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision on Tuesday to increase the cash rate by 0.25 per cent, the bank will pass on the rate hike to its customers.
The change will be effective May 12 for existing customers and the bank said home loan variable interest rates will increase by 0.25 per cent for new and existing customers on May 16.
Westpac is passing on the rate hike to customers.
(ABC News)

Deposit rates for Westpac Life total variable rate with bonus interest will increase by 0.25 per cent to 4.50 per cent on May 12, while Westpac eSaver total variable rate will increase by the same amount for new customers for the first five months, on May 12.
Westpac chief executive of its consumer and business banking, Chris de Bruin, said customers were looking carefully at their budgets as interest rates rise.
"While many are adjusting to making higher repayments, we understand others may need extra help," he said.
"To assist we're reaching out to some customers we believe may need additional support."
Macquarie said it was increasing variable home loan reference rates by 0.25 percentage points, effective May 19.
Macquarie’s savings account welcome rate is increasing by 0.25 percentage points for the first four months on balances up to $250,000, effective May 9.

image.altText: Two men in traditional Indian dress sit next to each other as part of a same-sex marriage union.

items.synopsis: India's Hindu nationalist government and religious leaders are staunchly opposing same-sex marriage as a landmark case plays out in the country's Supreme Court, but others say there is nothing to fear.

title.children: 'Complete havoc': How could legalising same-sex marriage play out in conservative India?
